origin_history: Seeds planted on Nov 12, 2025 in the left section.
Shares the window box with Scotch Bonnet and Jalape\xf1o.
whats_been_logged: The plant is now in an active early-seedling phase with expanding true leaves, steady moisture conditions, and well-aerated soil following recent adjustments. The plant has shown consistent daily growth, healthy leaf development, and stable soil chemistry, while monitoring has centered on moisture behavior through rain cycles and early preventive pest management across the shared container.
current_state: The plant shows healthy early vegetative growth with noticeably larger true leaves, expanding leaf mass, and upright, firm stems. Leaf color is an even, vibrant green with no signs of chlorosis, wilting, or disease. The soil remains well-structured and aerated despite recent saturation, and the plant is responding positively to warm temperatures and strong light.

timeline.what_i_should_see: Seeds in soil (no visible activity yet)
Stem thickening and new leaf growth
Bushy vegetative stage, no buds yet

journal.conditions: Sunny with a high of 82\xb0F dropping to 66\xb0F overnight.
journal.observations: The plant remains upright and actively growing, but chewing damage has increased noticeably with multiple fresh holes present across several leaves. New growth remains mostly intact, and overall vigor is still strong. Soil is beginning to dry down after recent sunny conditions.
journal.actions: Water the window box evenly using moderate hose flow for 30\u201345 seconds, then apply Captain Jack\u2019s Dead Bug to the entire planter, spraying both sides of leaves and inner canopy.
journal.next_steps: Monitor daily for new chew damage over the next 48\u201372 hours. Reapply insecticide only if feeding continues. Recheck moisture with the next probe reading to track dry-down rate.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Discussed escalating chew damage and confirmed insecticide treatment is now appropriate; explained why only one pepper may be targeted.

photos.caption: Overhead view showing increased chewing damage across multiple leaves with intact new growth.
Close-up of fresh chew holes with clean edges on mid-canopy leaves.
Side view showing healthy stems and active growth despite increasing leaf damage.
Angled view highlighting localized pest feeding concentrated on this plant within the shared window box.

journal.conditions: Patchy fog before 8 AM, otherwise partly sunny with a high near 84\xb0F dropping to around 61\xb0F overnight.
journal.observations: The plant remains in healthy early vegetative growth with expanding leaf mass, upright stems, and consistent green coloration. Minor chew holes are present on a few leaves but are limited in number and not affecting new growth. Soil is moist and well aerated with no signs of compaction or stress.
journal.actions: Do not water or apply insecticide today. Maintain full sun exposure and continue monitoring for any increase in pest activity.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture tomorrow midday and water only if levels fall below 40\u201345 mS/cm. Monitor leaves daily for changes in chew damage pattern before considering treatment.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Discussed whether observed leaf holes are new chew damage and whether insecticide is warranted; confirmed damage is minor and does not justify treatment at this time.

photos.caption: Side view showing early vegetative growth with healthy leaf expansion and minor chew holes on older leaves.
Angled overhead view highlighting healthy canopy development and limited pest damage.

journal.conditions: Partly sunny with a high of 83\xb0F dropping to 67\xb0F overnight.
journal.observations: The plant continues healthy early vegetative growth with expanding leaf size, upright stems, and even green coloration. New growth appears slightly lighter green, consistent with active expansion. Soil is fully saturated from morning rainfall but remains well-structured, with no signs of pooling, collapse, or plant stress.
journal.actions: Do not water today. Maintain full sun exposure and allow soil to dry naturally following rainfall.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture tomorrow afternoon after drainage and evaporation. Water only if moisture falls below 45\u201350 mS/cm. Continue monitoring leaf expansion and overall vigor.

photos.caption: Side view showing early vegetative growth with broadening leaves and upright, firm stems after rainfall.
Angled overhead view highlighting increasing leaf mass, healthy coloration, and evenly saturated soil following morning rain.

journal.conditions: Mostly sunny with a high near 80\xb0F dropping to around 65\xb0F overnight.
journal.observations: The plants continue healthy early vegetative growth with broadening true leaves, upright stems, and even green coloration. Leaf posture remains firm and responsive to light with no signs of wilt or stress. The soil surface was dry and lightly crusted from wind exposure, but the root zone remains adequately moist and well aerated after gentle surface fluffing.
journal.actions: Do not water today. Maintain full sun exposure and allow possible overnight rain to contribute to rehydration.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture after overnight weather passes. Water only if moisture drops below 35\u201340 mS/cm and rainfall does not occur. Continue light surface loosening if wind causes crusting.

photos.caption: Side view showing upright early vegetative plants with healthy leaf expansion after windy conditions.
Angled overhead view highlighting broadening true leaves and evenly colored foliage.
Wide view of the planter section showing well-spaced plants and loosened soil surface following wind-driven drying.

journal.conditions: A 20 percent chance of showers and thunderstorms, partly sunny with a high of 81\xb0F dropping to 63\xb0F overnight.
journal.observations: The plants are in active early vegetative growth with noticeably broader true leaves, improved node spacing, and upright, stable stems. Leaf color is evenly green with no signs of chlorosis, curl, or pest damage. Soil is moist but well-aerated following recent rain, and the plants show no signs of stress despite breezy conditions.
journal.actions: Do not water today. Maintain full sun exposure and allow natural airflow to continue soil dry-down.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture when levels approach 40 mS/cm. Continue monitoring leaf expansion and stem strength over the next several days before introducing any fertilizer.

photos.caption: Side view showing early vegetative growth with expanding leaf mass and upright stems under breezy conditions.
Angled view highlighting healthy node spacing, broadening leaves, and well-structured soil surface.
Overhead view showing uniform leaf color, increasing canopy presence, and stable spacing within the planter section.

journal.conditions: Showers likely with a high of 81\xb0F dropping to 63\xb0F overnight.
journal.observations: The plant is transitioning into early vegetative growth with noticeably larger true leaves and increased spacing between nodes. Leaf color is evenly green and healthy, stems are upright and firm, and no signs of wilt, disease, or stress are present. Soil is fully saturated from rainfall but remains well-structured and aerated with no surface pooling.
journal.actions: Do not water today. Maintain full sun exposure and allow soil to dry naturally following rainfall.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture once levels fall below 60 mS/cm. Resume watering only after additional dry-down. Continue monitoring leaf expansion and stem strength over the next several days.

photos.caption: Side view showing early vegetative growth with expanding true leaves and upright, firm stems.
Overhead view highlighting increased leaf size, healthy coloration, and evenly saturated soil after rainfall.

journal.conditions: Mostly sunny with a high of 79\xb0F dropping to 62\xb0F overnight.
journal.observations: The seedlings remain upright and healthy, with expanding true leaves. Leaf color is bright green, and stems are firm. Soil moisture is slightly below ideal for this stage, but the plant remains stable with no signs of stress or nutrient imbalance.
journal.actions: Monitor moisture levels closely and water if moisture falls below 40 mS/cm. Continue maintaining full sun exposure to encourage steady growth.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture tomorrow morning and adjust watering as necessary. Continue monitoring leaf health and soil conditions.

photos.caption: Healthy seedlings with expanding true leaves, bright green and upright.
Overhead view showing seedlings and settled, well-aerated soil surface.

journal.conditions: Mostly Sunny with a high of 73\xb0F dropping to 53\xb0F overnight.
journal.observations: The plant appears healthy and stable with expanding true leaves that are beginning to lay flatter as growth shifts from vertical to lateral development. Leaf color remains evenly pepper-green with firm structure and upright stems. Soil surface is settled and well-aerated with no signs of crusting, collapse, or excess moisture. No visual indicators of cold stress, wilting, or nutrient imbalance are present.
journal.actions: Do not water today. Maintain full sun exposure to continue strengthening stems and supporting leaf expansion.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture tomorrow morning. Water only if moisture drops below 40 mS/cm. Continue monitoring overnight temperatures and early leaf progression.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Discussed whether overnight temperatures in the low 50s\xb0F are a concern; confirmed these conditions are safe for pepper seedlings and do not require intervention.

photos.caption: Afternoon view showing healthy seedlings with expanding true leaves and stable posture.
Overhead view of evenly spaced seedlings and settled, well-aerated soil surface.

journal.conditions: Mostly Sunny with a high of 77\xb0F dropping to 52\xb0F overnight.
journal.observations: Seedlings appear vigorous with upright posture and expanding true leaves showing bright, even coloration. Dew from the cool morning has not caused stress, and the soil remains loose and aerated. Moisture at 80.00 mS/cm is ideal for early root development, with no signs of damping-off, nutrient imbalance, or overwatering.
journal.actions: Do not water today. Maintain full sun exposure to support leaf thickening and healthy stem development.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture tomorrow morning as warming conditions may increase evaporation. Water only if moisture drops below 40 mS/cm. Continue monitoring early leaf progression and soil aeration.

photos.caption: Morning photo showing vigorous seedlings with upright growth and dew-kissed leaves.
Overhead view of expanding true leaves and well-aerated soil.

journal.conditions: Slight Chance T-storms then Showers Likely with a high of 83\xb0F dropping to 63\xb0F overnight.
journal.observations: Seedlings appear vigorous with widening true leaves and bright, even coloration. Leaf surfaces show healthy sheen consistent with elevated humidity. Soil is evenly damp but not waterlogged, matching the 90.00 mS/cm moisture reading. No signs of wilt, rot, fungal spotting, or damping-off. Growth is steady and well supported by warm temperatures and strong ambient light.
journal.actions: Do not water today. Keep soil surface loose around, but not against, the seedling stems. Maintain current sun exposure.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture tomorrow morning after the rain system passes. Water only if moisture falls below around 40 mS/cm. Continue monitoring leaf thickness and color as true leaves mature.

photos.caption: Digital probe screenshot showing 12/08 soil readings for Orange Cal Wonder.
Seedlings with bright expanding true leaves and evenly moist soil.

journal.conditions: Sunny with a high near 86\xb0F, patchy morning fog, light south winds 5\u20138 mph. Tonight partly cloudy with a low around 66\xb0F. Tomorrow mostly sunny with a high near 87\xb0F and a slight chance of showers.
journal.observation: Seedlings show strong, healthy growth with well-developed cotyledons and expanding true leaves. Color remains bright green with no signs of stress, wilt, or nutrient deficiency. Soil moisture at 80 mS/cm reflects a comfortably moist profile following warm sunny conditions, and the soil appears evenly hydrated without pooling or anaerobic patches.
journal.actions: Do not water today. Current moisture level is appropriate and above the threshold for seedling watering.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture tomorrow morning. Water only if moisture falls below 40 mS/cm.

photos.caption: Digital probe screenshot showing 12/07 soil readings for Orange Cal Wonder.
Photo showing healthy seedlings with expanding true leaves under sunny midday conditions.

journal.conditions: Mostly sunny with a high of 84\xb0F dropping to 64\xb0F overnight. Soil was fully dried out by early afternoon before watering.
journal.observation: Seedlings remain vigorous with expanding cotyledons and developing true leaves. Leaf color is bright and even. Soil was bone dry earlier in the day due to strong sun exposure, but after watering, moisture readings reflect rehydration, not waterlogging.
journal.actions: No additional watering today. Allow soil to oxygenate overnight.
journal.next_steps: Check moisture tomorrow morning; water only if moisture falls below ~40 mS/cm.
follow_up: [5:35 PM] Applied Captain Jack's Dead Bug due to flea beetle bites appearing on other pepper plants in the same window planter.

photos.caption: Digital probe screenshot showing 12/04 soil readings for Orange Cal Wonder.
Photo showing healthy Orange Cal Wonder seedlings after rehydration, with developing true leaves.

journal.conditions: Mostly sunny with a high of 82\xb0F dropping to 62\xb0F overnight.
journal.observation: Seedlings show healthy growth with enlarging cotyledons and emerging true leaves. Soil has transitioned out of the saturated phase and is now drying appropriately.
journal.actions: Water today due to moisture reading of 37 mS/cm. Apply 1/4 cup of water.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture tomorrow morning for stability in the 45\u201360 range.
follow_up: [1:50 PM] Added 1/4 cup of water due to low moisture reading.

photos.caption: Digital probe screenshot showing 12/03 soil readings.
Seedlings with early true leaves after watering.

journal.conditions: Cloudy with a high of 72\xb0F dropping to 57\xb0F overnight. Clear conditions expected around 6 PM.
journal.observation: Seedlings remain healthy despite saturated soil from recent weather. pH is slightly low due to cool, wet conditions but still safe.
journal.actions: Do not water. Allow natural drying as conditions clear.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture tomorrow morning; maintain sun exposure.

photos.caption: Probe screenshot showing 11/28 readings.
Seedlings in saturated but draining soil.

journal.conditions: Cloudy with a high of 81\xb0F dropping to 65\xb0F. Rainy conditions expected around 6 PM.
journal.observation: Seedlings upright and green with early true-leaf development. Soil is moist from recent rain but draining well.
journal.actions: Do not water today. Protect from direct heavy rainfall if possible.
journal.next_steps: Recheck after storms pass.

photos.caption: Digital probe screenshot for 11/27.
Seedlings healthy after rain.

journal.conditions: Mostly cloudy with a high of 84\xb0F dropping to 67\xb0F overnight. Thunderstorms expected around 4 PM.
journal.observation: Multiple seedlings emerging with bright green cotyledons. Soil moist but not oversaturated despite recent rain.
journal.actions: Do not water; prepare for thunderstorms by reducing direct exposure.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture after storm cycle.

photos.caption: Probe screenshot 11/26.
Photo showing multiple healthy new seedlings.

journal.conditions: Partly cloudy with a high of 81\xb0F dropping to 61\xb0F overnight.
journal.observation: Multiple seedlings newly emerged with bright green cotyledons. Soil moisture ideal.
journal.actions: No amendments or fertilizer. Avoid disturbing young seedlings.
journal.next_steps: Monitor moisture daily.

photos.caption: Probe screenshot for 11/24.
Photo of newly emerged seedlings.

journal.conditions: Sunny with a high of 84\xb0F dropping to 60\xb0F overnight.
journal.observations: Soil remains in ideal germination range with stable pH at 6.45, moderate moisture at 57 mS/cm, and warm soil temperature of 82\xb0F. Nutrients are balanced with low salt levels, and the soil surface in the photo appears even, moist but not saturated, and free of crusting or fungus. No sprouts are visible yet, but conditions are the most germination-ready recorded so far.
journal.actions: No actions needed. Do not water or amend today.
journal.next_steps: Check moisture in 24 hours and water lightly only if it drops below 40 mS/cm. Continue full sun exposure. Watch for soil lifting as a sign of imminent sprouting.

photos.caption: Afternoon photo of the Orange Cal Wonder planter with level, moist soil under full sun.

journal.conditions: Mostly sunny with a high of 83\xb0F dropping to 64\xb0F overnight.
journal.observations: No sprouts visible. Soil moisture at 60.00 mS/cm is ideal for pepper germination. pH at 6.20 is within optimal range. EC and salt are mildly elevated but still safe. Fertility has increased as nutrients redistributed following earlier overwatering. Soil surface appears even, moist but not saturated, and free of compaction. Photos show stable surface texture and intact seed placement area. Soil temperature around 82\xb0F is highly favorable for germination.
journal.actions: No actions needed today. Do not water or amend. Maintain full sun exposure to support soil warmth.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture and pH in 24 hours. Water lightly only if moisture falls below 40 mS/cm. Continue full sun exposure. Expect possible sprouting within the next 3\u20137 days if soil temperatures remain above 75\xb0F.

photos.caption: Midday photo of the Orange Cal Wonder center section in the pepper box with moist, level soil under full sun.

journal.conditions: Mostly sunny with a high around 82-85\xb0F dropping to 64\xb0F overnight.
journal.observations: No sprouts visible. Soil moisture has decreased to 43.00 mS/cm, indicating moderate dryness. pH at 5.93 is slightly acidic but within acceptable range for germination. EC and salt remain low. Fertility has dropped, consistent with a nutrient-light early stage. Soil surface appears slightly drier but not compacted. Temperature is favorable for germination.
journal.actions: No watering or amendments needed. Allow soil to continue drying slightly before watering. Do not fertilize until sprouts appear.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture in 24 hours; water lightly if moisture falls below 35 mS/cm. Maintain full sun exposure and avoid fertilizer until seedlings have true leaves.
journal.q_and_a_summary: User asked if more lime should be added after accidental overwatering; guidance was to avoid adding lime, allow the soil to drain, and recheck moisture and pH the next day.
follow_up: [2:52 PM] Grandson over-watered entire pepper box; soil became saturated and most lime in adjacent sections washed away. No additional lime should be added to the Orange Cal Wonder section; allow soil to drain naturally and recheck moisture and pH tomorrow.

photos.caption: Morning photo of the Orange Cal Wonder soil surface showing moderate dryness before the overwatering event.
Follow-up photo of the Orange Cal Wonder section after accidental overwatering, with saturated soil and reduced visible lime in neighboring sections.

journal.conditions: Partly cloudy with a high of 82\xb0F dropping to 65\xb0F overnight.
journal.observations: No sprouts visible. Soil remains moderately moist with a moisture reading of 62.00 mS/cm. pH at 6.85 is close to ideal. EC and salt levels remain low. Fertility is low but acceptable for pre-germination. Soil surface is even and undisturbed. Lime in neighboring areas is not affecting the center section.
journal.actions: No actions needed today. Do not water or amend.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture and pH in 24 hours. Expect germination once soil consistently reaches 70\u201375\xb0F.

photos.caption: Pepper box planter showing the Orange Cal Wonder center section with lime-treated Scotch Bonnet and Jalape\xf1o sections on either side.

journal.conditions: Mostly sunny with a high of 81\xb0F dropping to 61\xb0F overnight.
journal.observations: No sprouts visible. Soil remains evenly moist with a moisture reading of 68.00 mS/cm. pH has rebounded from a prior acidic reading to slightly alkaline. EC and salt levels are within safe ranges. Soil temperature remains cool for peppers. Soil surface shows no compaction.
journal.actions: No actions needed today.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture and pH within 24 hours.

journal.conditions: Partly sunny with afternoon temperatures around 73\xb0F and an expected overnight low in the upper 50s\xb0F.
journal.observations: Digital probe reading shows very acidic soil at pH 4.30 with moderate moisture and light nutrient levels. Conditions are too acidic for peppers but otherwise stable.
journal.actions: Apply a small amount of baking-soda water to gently raise pH; do not add lime.
journal.next_steps: Recheck pH and moisture within 24 hours.
journal.q_and_a_summary: User asked whether baking-soda water should be used only for the center section and lime for the left section; confirmed.

journal.conditions: Mostly sunny with morning temperature near 67\xb0F, rising to about 74\xb0F by noon and cooling to 57\xb0F overnight.
journal.observations: No sprouts visible. Analog readings show moisture in the ideal 6\u20137 range, fertility moving upward, and pH around 6. The soil surface looks evenly moist without compaction.
journal.actions: Added about one-third quart of diluted fertilizer to boost nutrients.
journal.next_steps: Monitor moisture and avoid more fertilizer until after germination.
journal.q_and_a_summary: User asked for notes; guidance emphasized avoiding further fertilizer and watching moisture.

journal.conditions: Cool clear morning around 62\xb0F with full sun.
journal.observations: Seeds were sown at roughly \xbc inch depth in dry, alkaline soil with low fertility. Soil appeared dry and slightly coarse before watering.
journal.actions: Moistened the entire box with mild vinegar water to begin lowering pH.
journal.next_steps: Recheck soil pH and moisture within 24\u201348 hours.
journal.q_and_a_summary: User asked whether more steps were needed; guidance was to wait and monitor.

photos.caption: Seed packet for Orange Cal Wonder pepper photographed before planting.
